awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Online Learning-based Underwater Acoustic Communications and Networking
awd_abstract_narration:
Underwater acoustic communication networks are the enabling technologies for unmanned, in situ, and real-time aquatic monitoring in a wide range of applications, such as scientific studies, pollution detection, offshore exploration, and tactical surveillance. The lifespan of underwater systems varies from a few years to decades, while the spatiotemporal dynamics of underwater acoustic environments at multiple scales pose grand challenges to efficient and reliable acoustic data transmission. The objective of this project is to develop a fundamental and systematic online-learning-based framework for underwater acoustic communications and networking, where the underwater acoustic system 1) models and predicts the long-term dynamics of the acoustic environment, and 2) proactively adapts its communication and networking strategy to the dynamics of the environment, thereby maximizing the long-term system performance in the aspects of energy efficiency, spectrum efficiency, and transmission reliability. Through explicit learning about its environment, the proposed framework will allow harmonious co-existence with other acoustic systems, including marine animals, to achieve eco-friendly operation. This project's research will be integrated with education through summer youth K-12 outreach, curriculum development, undergraduate and graduate student training that will be particularly tailored to females and underrepresented minorities, and collaboration with an underwater robotics team from the local Dollar Bay High School. These activities are designed to motivate and better train rural, female, minority, and economically disadvantaged students to pursue STEM careers.


This project tackles fundamental challenges in online-learning-based underwater acoustic communications and networking by innovating across three interrelated domains. First, novel signal processing and sparse learning techniques will be developed to model and predict the large-scale dynamics and the statistical distribution of small-scale fading of underwater acoustic environments, including the acoustic transmission loss, ambient soundscape, and statistical characterization of external (anthropogenic and marine animal) acoustic sources. Second, an optimization framework will be developed, based on the acoustic environment prediction, for joint transmission power control, link scheduling, node-cooperative routing, and autonomous vehicle mobility control to achieve high network utility and harmonious coexistence with other acoustic systems. Third, the acoustic environment exploration-exploitation tradeoff will be tackled in the Bayesian reinforcement learning framework, which will provide a principled approach to weighing the immediate reward of a communication and networking strategy and its associated long-term benefit of revealing the environment's dynamics. Leveraging the geographic advantage of Michigan Tech and the state-of-the-art facilities of Michigan Tech's Great Lakes Research Center, extensive field experiments will be conducted for acoustic measurement collection and for offline and online algorithm evaluation in a software-defined networking architecture. The methodologies and crosscutting techniques developed in this project can be applied to the design of intelligent radio-frequency communication networks.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to develop a fundamental and systematic framework for online learning-based underwater acoustic (UWA) communications and networking. The UWA communications and networking have been challenged by the large spatial and temporal dynamics of the marine environment. This project introduced machine learning techniques to model and predict the unknown variations in the UWA environment, and proactively adapt the communication and networking strategies to the environmental dynamics, thereby maximizing the long-term system performance.

This project made contributions to intelligent and adaptive UWA communications and networking in several aspects. Firstly, novel signal processing and machine learning techniques were developed to model the dynamics of critical UWA environment parameters, including generative adversarial networking for modeling and prediction of the UWA channel impulse responses, time series analyses for modeling and prediction of the UWA channel parameters, and estimation of the underwater/under-ice sound speed field in mobile networking. Secondly, a reinforcement learning framework was employed to adapt the communication and networking strategy to the environmental dynamics while achieving an optimal environment exploration-exploitation tradeoff. Algorithms were designed for adapting the transmission schedule, the modulation and coding, and the communication modality to the variation of UWA channels; and for trajectory planning of multiple autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) in unknown underwater/under-ice environments. And thirdly, interference modeling and mitigation algorithms were designed to achieve harmonious coexistence with other acoustic systems (e.g., sonar, ice cracking and marine animals).

Additionally, leveraging the geographic advantage of Michigan Tech and its state-of-the-art facilities, eight major field experiments (six stationary and two mobile) were conducted in underwater/under-ice scenarios with various geometric and water settings. The data set analyses revealed insightful characteristics of underwater/under-ice/stationary/mobile acoustic channels and their interaction with meteorological conditions. The obtained data has been organized as a database, consisting of millions of channel impulse response samples and corresponding real-time weather information at a minute-level sampling rate. The database will greatly facilitate future machine learning research for UWA communication and networking.

The research of this project shifts the existing UWA system operational paradigm from being environment-oblivious/reactive to environment-proactive. Through developing the signal processing and machine learning tools for UWA communications and networking, the research significantly boosted the energy efficiency, spectrum efficiency, and transmission reliability in long-term operating UWA systems. The research outcomes can be applied to existing ocean observation activities, such as the Ocean Observatory Initiative, and to the short-term deployments of aquatic instruments or mobile platforms for various applications. The large data sets collected during field experiments contribute to the big ocean data analytics and machine learning for underwater research. The methodologies and crosscutting techniques developed can be applied to other research domains, such as the 5G/6G networks, cognitive radio networks, vehicular networks and internet of things.

The research of this project was closely integrated with education through K-12 outreach, curriculum development and student involvement. In total six Ph.D. students, six master students (including two female students) and twelve undergraduate students were involved in the project. Three PhD dissertations, four master dissertations, eleven technical conference papers, seven journal articles, seven invited presentations, two undergraduate senior design projects and one NSF REU project have been produced. The project topics were also introduced into the curriculum of eleven undergraduate/graduate classes. K-12 outreach was pursued through collaboration with the Student Organization of Aquatic Robotics at the local Dollar Bay High School, presentations and demonstrations in the local annual Water Festival for Grades 4-8 students, and during the pre-college outreach, with in total about 200 students/parents/teachers participated. This project contributed significantly to the workforce development in the fields of marine sciences and engineering, electrical engineering, and computer sciences and engineering.
